title: Legend of the Cybermen
author: Mike Maddox
filename: 135 - Legend of the Cybermen - Mike Maddox_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
PRE-CREDITS: REPRISE FROM THE WRECK OF THE TITAN
Och, come on! Stop joshing. We must be somewhere.
Somewhere, nowhere, everywhere. The normal rules of space and time don’t apply in this place. I came here once before. With Zoe and... and you.

With me? Sorry, Doctor, but you must be mistaken. I think I’d remember coming here. It’s not exactly a sight you see everyday, now is it? A great big blank. A white mist. It’s more like something out of a book!
(FX: A STRANGE WHIRRING, RIPPING SOUND GRADUALLY APPROACHES
That’s exactly what this is, Jamie. But not just one book. Any book. All books.
(IS THE DOCTOR MAD?) Oh aye. Is that a fact?
It’s about the only fact you’ll find here. This is a land where fiction is king.
Doctor. Something’s coming out of the mist. People, by the looks of it. People in armour.
FX: THE WHIRRING, RIPPING SOUND GETS LOUDER
Not people, Jamie, no: robots. (THE NOISE STOPS) White Robots.
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
SCENE 1: EXT. THE VOID (CONTINUOUS)
(FX: 4 x WHITE ROBOTS’ NOISE AGAIN, AS IF IN NEUTRAL — OR IN
(BEAT) Quite a welcoming committee, aren’t they, Jamie?
(HUSHED) What are they, Doctor?
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 3
Robots, Jamie. Mechanical puppets.
Puppets without strings?
Oh, they have strings all right. Invisible ones, pulled by (ALOUD, SO ‘MASTER’ CAN HEAR) a very imaginative puppet master!
FX: ROBOTS FALL SILENT
And you’ve met this fellow before?
I don’t think so. These White Robots look a little more advanced than when we — when I — was last here. I suspect that, like them, the Master has been upgraded.
And he’s the man who turned Myra and John and Nemo into paper?
If I’m right, Jamie, then Myra and John and Nemo never really existed — just fictional characters from this Land of Fiction. It’s a trap, Jamie, and we walked straight into it.
Why?
Why did we walk in or why is it a trap?
Either.
Someone wants us here. Someone wants us back. That’s why we were pulled out of our rightful place in time and brought here.
This Master person?

Most likely. Nemo was sent to fetch us, remember. Presumably he was working for the Master. And that’s whom these White Robots have been sent to take us to. (TO THE ROBOTS) All right, Robots: take us to your Master! (NOTHING) I said —
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 4
FX: ROBOTS WHIRR MENACINGLY
Maybe they’re not the welcoming committee. Maybe they’re the execution squad.

No, Jamie. Whoever brought us here did so for a reason. If they meant to harm us they could have done so already, by any one of a thousand different means. This place brings creatures from the imagination to life — and not necessarily good ones.
Then I’11l try not to think of any.

Don’t worry, it’s not your imagination at work here. Whoever runs this place, they remember other people’s creations. Never allowed to invent their own characters, they merely come up with new adventures for existing ones. I wonder what he’s like, this new Master. The last chap was rather [endearing —]
FX: ROBOTS WHIRR AGAIN
Hey, Doctor, I think they want us to go with them.
I think you’re right. (TO ROBOTS) This way, I take it? You’1l have to help us, we’ve rather lost our sense of direction.
Alright, alright. Don’t push-!
(SOTTO) Jamie. When I say run —
Aye, what?
I keep forgetting, you don’t remember. .. Run?
Where to?
Anywhere they’re not. (BEAT) Run!!!
FX: THEY RUN. ROBOTS WHIRR ON THE SPOT. CROSSFADE TO:
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 5
SCENE 2: EXT. THE VOID
FX: DOCTOR AND JAMIE RUN TO HALT
(CATCHING BREATH) Have we lost them-?
I think so. For now.
Hey — is it me, or has it got brighter?
It’s you. It’s not brighter; it’s not dimmer. It’s not anything. We only see it as being white because —
Because that’s what it is.

Jamie. My TARDIS looks like a blue police box. It isn’t, though. In the same way this place looks like a white void. Which reminds me: I wonder where they put the old girl? The last we saw of her, she was in the hold of the Titan.
(BARELY FOLLOWING ALL THIS) You mean we’re inside someone’s TARDIS?
No. Come on.
Come on where?
This way.
What do you mean “This way”? It could take us into the middle of nowhere.
Jamie, this is the middle of nowhere. Any direction we chose will take us further from here. It’s like standing on the North Pole. Any direction you walk in has to be South. (WALKING) Come on.
Where?
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 6
(POINTEDLY) This way!
Och, alright — (FOLLOWS)
FX: CROSSFADE TO:
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 7
SCENE 3: EXT. THE VOID
FX: FOOTSTEPS OF JAMIE AND THE DOCTOR
(WALKING) Hey, Doctor.
(WALKING) What?
(WALKING) Why do our feet make noises when we’re walking on nothing?
(STOPPING) You really do ask the most peculiar questions
sometime.
(STOPPING) I was just trying to make [conversation] —
(SUDDENLY HUSHED) Shhh!
(HUSHED) What is it?
(HUSHED) I don’t know. You were making conversation over it.
FX: MUSIC FADING IN. “SOLDIER, SOLDIER” ON FIFE AND DRUMS
(HUSHED) There! That’s it!
The drums... the fife...
FX: DISTANT CREAKING — 3 x CLOCKWORK ROBOTS APPROACHING
Look! Over there!
Redcoats! (RETRIEVING DIRK) Och, well, if they want a fight —
Jamie, put that knife away this instant. Those aren’t real Redcoats.
Aye, well, real enough to feel the point of my [dirk —]
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 8
Look again.
They’re wooden-! Wooden Redcoats!
Toys, Jamie. Propelled by clockwork keys.
Aye, but life-size! (FX: CREAKING STOPS) Hey, they’ve stopped. Have they seen us?
Don’t move. It could be that their sensors respond only to movement.
Eh-? What d’you mean, ‘sensors’-?
The pieces in their caps — (FX: CREAKING RESUMES, SOLDIERS APPROACHING) Too late. They’re coming this way.
I know. When you say “Run” —
On three, then.
Right.
Three! (RUNS)
What?
(STOPPED) Come on, Jamie!
You didn’t say [“run” —] (ALARM) Doctor, look out! Behind you!
FX: 3 MORE X CLOCKWORK SOLDIERS APPROACHING
Oh, no. Three more of them. Other way, Jamie-!
I’1l not leave you!
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 9
For heaven’s sake, run-!!!
FX: DOCTOR AND JAMIE RUN IN DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS. FADE
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 10
SCENE 4: EXT. THE VOID
FX: FADE UP ON THE DOCTOR CALLING OUT
(FX: ECHO) Jamie..! (FX: BIGGER ECHO) Where are you? (FX: EVEN
ECHO) Jamie...! (TO SELF) Oh, this is hopeless, I can’t

see more than three feet in this mist. (LOUDLY, TO UNSEEN ‘MASTER’) Trying to split us up, are you, ‘Master’? Is that your game, divide and conquer? Well, it won’t work. Do you hear me, wherever you are-? Who-ever you are-? If you’ve something to say to me, I wish you’d come on and say it-!!!
(SLIGHTLY OFF) Hello.
At last.
I said, [“Hello” —]
(TURNING) Hello. And might I enquire just what you think you’re [playing at —] (BREAKS OFF, SURPRISED) Oh.
(WALKING FORWARD) Thank goodness for that. This far out from the gateway you see all sorts of phantasmagoria. Trouble is, half the time they don’t see you back.
Young man, I may be many things, but a phantasm is not one of them.
Then what are you?
“What?” I am not a “What”, I ama “Who”.
My apologies, sir. To who [sic] do I owe the pleasure?
I am known as the Doctor.
Then I’m pleased to make your acquaintance. What are you doing out here, Doctor? The Void is a bad place to be at any time, especially now.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 11
I’m looking for my friend. We became separated.
That makes two of us.
And you are?
Sergeant Jack Dawkins, Esquire. Better known to friends and enemies alike as —
. the Artful Dodger?!?
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 12
SCENE 5: EXT. THE VOID/INT. BEHIND DOOR
FX: FADE UP ON JAMIE CALLING OUT
(FX: ECHO) Doctor..! (FX: BIGGER ECHO) Where are you? (FX: EVEN
ECHO) Doctor..! (TO SELF) Och, this is hopeless, I can’t
see more than three feet in this mist. How’m I ever going to find my way out of this [place-?]
FX: WHOOSHING SOUND, WHICH STOPS ABRUPTLY
What’s this? A door? (ALOUD) So I ask for something and then it appears, is that it? Alright then — (CLEARS THROAT) A
bottle of whisky, and a lassie with a cheeky smile! (BEAT; TO SELF) No? Och well, always worth a try —
FX: DOOR CREAKS OPEN

(ALOUD) Och, I’m not going in there, it’s pitch dark! Could be anything in there. A three-headed, five-eyed, bloodthirsty beastie. And his big brother! (BEAT; TO SELF) But what’s the choice? Stay here forever, or chance it. Alright then, Jamie boy — here goes...
FX: JAMIE WALKS THROUGH
(ALOUD) Right then, I’m in. Hey, is it too much to ask for a candle-? —
(FAINT, FAR DISTANT, AND MUFFLED THROUGH SPACE HELMET) Jamie,
no! It’s a trap!
What was that-? (BEAT) Hello-? Hello, is there someone there?
FX: DOOR SLAMS BEHIND
(RUSHING OVER) Och, no — the door! (STOPS, BEAT) Hey, but
there’s nothing here. No door, no nothing.
(FX: MECHANICAL CLUNKING, RUMBLING BENEATH — A TRAP DOOR OPENING)
(SLOWLY) Door... ‘Trap’... (REALISATION) Trap [doooo0o00o0or! I]
FX: HE’S FALLING. FADE
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 13
SCENE 6: EXT. THE VOID
Forgive me if this sounds odd, but you are the Artful Dodger?
I am the what Artful Dodger?
Pickpocket, Fagin, Oliver Twist, that Artful Dodger.
You seem like a remarkably well-informed gentleman, sir.
Oh, I am. It’s just, you’re not quite how Mr D[ickens] — (STOPS, CORRECTS HIMSELF) .. I mean, how I imagined you.
And how did you imagine me?
Younger, for one thing —
I was twenty-three last birthday —
. and whereas the top hat and turned-up coat is all as expected, you’re not usually depicted as carrying a very advanced laser cannon of some kind.
(FX: KA-CHUNK) Locked and loaded! Can’t be too careful.
No. Tell me, what year is this? To you, I mean.

The year, sir? Well, given that we’re stood outside the normal parameters of time and space, I’m not sure that’s a meaningful measure. We may be following a by-and-large standard linear narrative, but out here continuity is distinctly malleable.
I must have read Oliver Twist half-a-dozen times or more, but I don’t recall the Artful Dodger ever using that sort of language.
I’ve travelled. Broadens the mind, you know.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 14
So I believe. So how did you end up here, Dodger? Wandering around the void like this?
Long range scouting patrol. Trying to detect enemy movements. Oliver and me, we came through together — but we was attacked, and got separated.
Attacked, yes. That weapon of yours. May I take a closer look at it?
You may not.
I can assure you I mean you no harm.
That’s because you haven’t got a great big gun.
Yes, but — it doesn’t fit with your time period, does it?
And again he talks of “time”. No, it’s not from my “time”. You expect me to come out here with an antiquated weapon, given the threat level?
Ah, but it wouldn’t be antiquated to you, would it? To you, a breech-loading Enfield rifle would be contemporary. State of the art.

And completely useless. Here, look. And no, you may not touch. (FX: EJECTS CARTRIDGE — CLUNK) High velocity round, with an armour-piercing tip, see? The shell contains a cocktail of radioactive metals, held in an acetone suspension.
In a what-?
(CHANGING SUBJECT) You’re worried about your friend, aren’t you?
Jamie. Yes. Will you help me find him?
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 15
I’ll give it a go. With any luck, he and Oliver will have found each other, and we can all stop worrying. You armed?
No.
Shame.
I’ve never thought so. Come on.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 16
SCENE 7: INT. UNDERGROUND PASSAGE
FX: DRIPPING WATER. ECHOES
(COMING ROUND) Och, my head. I’m getting too old for this. Still — (GETTING TO FEET) Nothing broken, at least. (CALLING
OUT) Hello? Anyone there?
(TO SELF) No answer. Aye, well — (WALKING) .. best foot forward. Least it’s a change from all that white. If I follow the passage around —
FX: WHITE ROBOTS APROACHING, DOWN PASSAGE
Oh. It’s you lot again, is it?
FX: WHITE ROBOTS STOP. WHIRRING IN NEUTRAL
Alright, alright, you’ve got me. Just don’t get to shooting, you ken? It’s not like I’m going anywhere, is it?
FX: WHITE ROBOTS WHIRRING
Can’t speak, eh? Or won’t?
FX: ROBOTS MARCHING
I’m coming, I’m coming. (TO SELF) Oh, Doctor. Where are you?
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 17
SCENE 8: EXT. THE VOID
(WALKING) It seems things have changed since last I was here.
(WALKING) You’re outside time. You’re here, so you’ve always been here.
(WALKING) I most certainly have not!
(WALKING) Just saying.
(WALKING) I am a Time Lord. I don’t need to be lectured on temporal tautologies by some penny dreadful pedant.
(STOPS) They’re all dead.
(STOPPED) Who are?
The Penny Dreadfuls. Rough sorts, fought in the first campaign with Todd’s irregulars. This was early on in the war. Enemy agent got in the camp one night and poisoned their gin.
“Early on”? “First”? You said time had no meaning here.
Not here in the Void, no. But the battle took place inside.
. Inside the Land of Fiction, you mean?
Precisely. The Void is just the nothing that surrounds it.
Yes, I remember. The last time I was here, we were led a merry dance all around the Void, until we arrived in the Land of Fiction itself.
And the White Robots shepherded you through, I suppose?
Shepherded? You make me sound like a sheep!
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 18
Herded, then.
No. That’s actually worse.
(SIGHS) Ushered. Thing is, if they catch you now, they’1ll take you somewhere far worse.
The last time — and don’t interrupt — the last time I was here, the White Robots didn’t want anyone harmed. I presume they obey the will of your new Master-?
(SCOFFING) Master? You really are behind the times, aren’t you? There’s no Master anymore. This place is run by the Mistress.
The Mistress? And why not? Female writers are frequently more inventive than their male counterparts. The Mistress of the Land of Fiction.
Yes, and in answer to your previous question: no, they don’t obey the will of the Mistress. We’ve been fighting them for as long as we can remember.
You mean — they’re your enemy? The White Robots?
Them, and them who’s behind them. They’re not from here, see?
What, they’re not f[ictional-?]

Fictional? It’s alright, you can say it. Some folks find it mightily offensive to be reminded of the fact, but not me. No. They came from outside, put here by whichever idiot built the computer that runs the place. And no, I’ve no idea who that was.
I see.
No, you don’t. You’re just saying that to fool yourself you’re in control of the situation. You’re as confused as anyone.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 19
Tell me about this war.
We’re losing. The Mistress assembled great armies to hold them back. But our enemy grows. As our troops fall, they swell the ranks of the enemy, converted almost at once.
They’re what?
Plagiarised, killed, won over. Look, Mister — we can’t stand here expositing, not when the Void is crawling with the enemy. There’s a gateway not far from here. We can use it to access the Land.
We could, but I’m not leaving my friend.
He'll be making his own way.
How? He’s as blind as I am here. I will not leave him lost and alone!
Oh I doubt he’s lost, Doctor. And besides, who said anything about him being alone?
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 20
SCENE 9: INT. UNDERGROUND PASSAGE
FX: AS BEFORE, DANK. WHITE ROBOTS MARCHING

(WALKING) I once had an uncle Duncan. Loving father, fierce warrior and the greatest piper in Scotland. The most boring man in the world. Now I’ve met you lot, I realise what an interesting fellow he was. Are you not going to say [anything? ]
FX: WHITE ROBOTS STOP WALKING
Och. You want us to stop, [do you-?]
(FX: SOUND OF FIFE AND DRUMS IN THE DISTANCE. CLOCKWORK
CLANKING)
Oh, I see. More of your wee Redcoat pals, is it?
FX: SOLDIERS HALT, BOOTS TO ATTENTION
(CALLING OUT, ENGLISH ACCENT) Halloa there! Shall we toast the King?
FX: SOLDIERS RAISE MUSKETS — CLOCKWORK ROTATES, JUDDERS
Alright, I was only having a wee joke. No need to go pointing your muskets at us, is there now-?
FX: WHITE ROBOTS WHIRR
(OFF, BEHIND SOLDIERS; MUFFLED, THROUGH SPACE HELMET) Jamie! Get down-!
Hey, who’s that at the back [there-?]
(OFF, BEHIND SOLDIERS; MUFFLED, THROUGH SPACE HELMET) Just do it, Jamie. Please-!
Well, if I [must-]
(FX: VOLLEY OF MUSKETS. THE WHITE ROBOTS EXPLODE, WHIRRING
DOWN)
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 21
BEAT
Well — what d’you lot go and kill them for? They weren’t hurtin’ anyone —
(APPROACHING; MUFFLED, THROUGH SPACE HELMET) Not yet, they weren’t!
(AMUSED) Oh, look. A wee feller with a bowl on his head.
(MUFFLED, THROUGH SPACE HELMET) What? Oh, the helmet. Hang on, I’1ll take it off. (BEAT, EFFORT) Sorry, it’s a bit stuck. Could you give me a hand?
Why don’t you get one of your solider boys to help you?
(MUFFLED, THROUGH SPACE HELMET) Oh, just do it would you? There’s a clip at the back.
Alright. — Let’s see now.
(MUFFLED, THROUGH SPACE HELMET) The helmet’s not strictly necessary, but it makes a useful bit of armour —
Just hold still a second —
FX: CLICK AND HISS OF SEALS BREAKING
Aye, that’s got it.
(BREATHING IN FRESH AIR) Oh yes, that’s much better. Hello Jamie! It’s me! It’s Zoe!
(NAME MEANS NOTHING TO HIM) .. ‘Zoe’?

(GUSHING) Don’t mind the clockwork soldiers, they’re my friends. They’ve been helping me, ever since I arrived in this awful place. Oh Jamie, I can’t believe it! It’s only been a month, but it feels like years! Oh, give me a hug —
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 22
(HUGGED, A BIT NONPLUSSED) Hey, steady on —
(BREAKING OFF) Oh, Jamie — it’s so good to see you again! Gosh, haven’t you got old?
I’m in the prime of my life, I’1ll have you know!
BEAT
Oh dear. You don’t remember me, do you-?
Hold on there. (SUDDENLY LEAPS TO WRONG CONCLUSION) Aye! Aye, I know who you are now —
Well, thank goodness for that —
Aye, I asked for you! “A lassie with a cheeky smile”. See, it worked!
Oh, no —
(CONFIDENTIALLY) Have you brought me some whiskey?
Certainly not! Really, you have no idea who I am?
I’m sure I’d remember.
I thought this might happen. Here.
What’s this?
What does it look like?
Looks like an apple.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 23
It’s a data retrieval cluster. You hold it to your head.
Why would I hold an apple to my head?
To help unlock your memory. Oh, just do it, will you?
I will not. I know my Bible. Sensible men getting led astray by lassies with apples.

Your name is James Robert McCrimmon. Piper of the Clan McCrimmon. You fought at the Battle of Culloden. After that, you joined the crew of the TARDIS, and travelled with them through [time and space —]
Och, you’ve been talking to the Doctor-!
I haven’t. Honestly. Look — it’s all true, I promise you!
It’s crazy talk! I mean, the Doctor’s no loon, but all that stuff — well, he’s got me mixed up with someone else, that’s what I’ve been thinking —
Oh, just do it, would you? (COQUETTISHLY) Please? For the sake of a cheeky smile-?
Aye, well, now there’s a reason. (TAKES APPLE) So — what, you want me to hold it to my forehead here, like this-?
That’s right.
Aye, well, I don’t see anything happening.
Just give it a moment. For the synapses to [engage-]
(FX: PSYCHEDELIC HUM BEGINS, RISING PROGRESSIVELY IN INTENSITY
(GIGGLES) Hey, there’s like a tickling. In my head —
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 24
I know. The next bit’s not so nice, I’m afraid —
Ah. Ah, that — that hurts a little now...
Those are your locked memories coming in.
Well I don’t like it! Stop it!
First in a trickle. Then in a flood. (FX: HOLD, ECHO ON ‘FLOOD’ )
HOWLS IN PAIN, THROUGH:
(FX: COMING IN THROUGH THE HUM, SOUNDS FROM JAMIE’S ORIGINAL
THE TARDIS TAKING OFF; DALEK GUNS;
WARBLES; YETI ROARS; ICE WARRIOR GUN... TO A CRESCENDO...
CUTS DEAD, QUICKLY. SILENCE)
Jamie? Are you alright?
(AS IF WINDED) Monsters. There were monsters, everywhere we went.
I know. I remember. Daleks and Ice Warriors and Quarks.
Quarks, aye. But it wasn’t all bad. I had — friends. Sailor Ben. Beanpole Polly, his duchess. Victoria, precious like china. Then there was —
. yes?
. then there was Zoe. Clever little Zoe. Just the same as you always were.
Oh, Jamie —
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 25

What the Doctor said... it was true. All of it. I’ve seen such wonders! I’ve walked on the moon. I’ve watched Atlantis sink beneath the waves. I’ve been to the other side of space and back again. And everywhere we went, there were monsters. (BEAT) Och, this is too much. My head!
It’s alright, Jamie, really it is. I don’t know what’s happened to you, but you’1ll soon be your old self again.
The Doctor! We were with the Doctor. Small and scruffy, he was, with a funny little gleam in his eye. And then —
. then the Time Lords caught up with us.

Aye, and sent us home. I woke up in the heather, in Scotland, thinkin’ I must have been knocked cold for a moment. But I remember it now. All of it. Aye, and I’ve been here before. In this place — the Land of Fiction! Och, Zoe, we’ve got to find the Doctor —
In a moment. You’ve still not said why it is you’re so old? Is it some kind of time distortion?
Will you stop that? I’m not old. I’m older, thank you very much, because I’ve lived a full and fruitful life. It’s only been a month, you said? For me, it’s been more like thirty years.
Oh Jamie! I’m so sorry.
Why? I’ve had a good life. Mostly. And if you think I’ve changed, just wait until you see the Doctor!
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 26
SCENE 10: EXT. THE VOID
FX: FOOTSTEPS TO STOP.
So now what?
You can’t see it, but there’s a gateway, a few hundred feet north of here.
How can this place have a north?
It doesn’t. It’s a convention I’m using to explain unreal geography. I was trained to navigate my way about in here.
The Artful Dodger was a Victorian street urchin pickpocket. He was not, in any version of the story, an inter-dimensional secret agent who prowls alternate realities hunting robots! Care to explain?
The Mistress gave us free will when she arrived. Most of us have risen to the challenge. True, there are some who’ve been hardened by conflict, become as cruel as the enemy we fight.
What the Dickens is going on here?
Oi! Do you mind?
An unfortunate turn of phrase. I apologise.
None of this is the fault of the Mistress, Doctor. She was not born to fight wars. She is gentle and kind, and this conflict breaks her heart. (BEAT) Does that — displease you?
Far from it, I think your Mistress sounds rather wonderful. So — the clockwork soldiers Jamie and I encountered. I take it they’ve gone over to this ‘enemy’, too?
No! No, they’re ours. Or they should be. Fictional constructs, front line of defence.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 27
They tried to kill us!
More like they were trying to warn you. You were in a part of the Void riddled with traps.
Well, what if Jamie walked into one?

Then he’1ll have been catapulted elsewhere. Figuratively speaking, I mean. But the soldiers will have gone after him, to protect him from the White Robots. The Mistress uses all manner of fanciful creations.
You know, I would very much like to meet this Mistress.
And so you shall. But first we must find your friend. (WALKING) Northwards!
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 28
SCENE 11: INT. UNDERGROUND PASSAGE
FX: CLOCKWORK SOLDIERS MARCHING, JAMIE AND ZOE FOLLOWING
You’re sure you can trust these soldiers of yours, Zoe?
They did just save your life.
Mebbe. But do they have to look like Redcoats?
(SIGHS) Come on, Jamie.
Where are they leading us? I don’t understand how this place has tunnels anyway.
It doesn’t. The enemy have extruded parts of their lair into the Void.
What, they live in these tunnels?
Not exactly. These are the cellars of Castle Frankenstein.
Castle who-?
The soldiers will find the way out, I promise. After all, they found you.
You mean, they were looking for me?
Well, yes. We came out here to find you. You, and the Doctor, of course. Do come on, Jamie!
Not so fast, hey? I’m not as — (STOPS SHORT OF SAYING ‘YOUNG’ )
Not as what?
Nothing. Come on, let’s go. Try and keep up, eh?
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 29
(EXCITEDLY) Look! Up there. Daylight.
Or something like daylight.
Come on. Let’s see what’s out there!
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 30

ZOE: Jamie? Are you alright?

JAMIE: What the Doctor said... it was true. All of it. I’ve seen such wonders! I’ve walked on the moon. I’ve watched Atlantis sink beneath the waves. I’ve been to the other side of space and back again. And everywhere we went, there were monsters. (BEAT) Och, this is too much. My head!

ZOE: In a moment. You’ve still not said why it is you’re so old? Is it some kind of time distortion?

DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 10: EXT. THE VOID
DOCTOR: So now what?
ARTFUL DODGER: You can’t see it, but there’s a gateway, a few hundred feet north of here.
DOCTOR: How can this place have a north?
ARTFUL DODGER: It doesn’t. It’s a convention I’m using to explain unreal geography. I was trained to navigate my way about in here.
DOCTOR: The Artful Dodger was a Victorian street urchin pickpocket. He was not, in any version of the story, an inter-dimensional secret agent who prowls alternate realities hunting robots! Care to explain?
ARTFUL DODGER: The Mistress gave us free will when she arrived. Most of us have risen to the challenge. True, there are some who’ve been hardened by conflict, become as cruel as the enemy we fight.
DOCTOR: What the Dickens is going on here?
ARTFUL DODGER: Oi! Do you mind?
DOCTOR: An unfortunate turn of phrase. I apologise.
ARTFUL DODGER: None of this is the fault of the Mistress, Doctor. She was not born to fight wars. She is gentle and kind, and this conflict breaks her heart. (BEAT) Does that — displease you?
DOCTOR: Far from it, I think your Mistress sounds rather wonderful. So — the clockwork soldiers Jamie and I encountered. I take it they’ve gone over to this ‘enemy’, too?
ARTFUL DODGER: No! No, they’re ours. Or they should be. Fictional constructs, front line of defence.
DOCTOR WHO: LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 27
DOCTOR: They tried to kill us!
ARTFUL DODGER: More like they were trying to warn you. You were in a part of the Void riddled with traps.
DOCTOR: Well, what if Jamie walked into one?
ARTFUL DODGER: Then he’1ll have been catapulted elsewhere. Figuratively speaking, I mean. But the soldiers will have gone after him, to protect him from the White Robots. The Mistress uses all manner of fanciful creations.
DOCTOR: You know, I would very much like to meet this Mistress.
ARTFUL DODGER: And so you shall. But first we must find your friend. (WALKING) Northwards!
DOCTOR WHO: LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 28

JAMIE: Castle who-?
ZOE: The soldiers will find the way out, I promise. After all, they found you.
JAMIE: You mean, they were looking for me?

JAMIE: Not so fast, hey? I’m not as — (STOPS SHORT OF SAYING ‘YOUNG’ )

JAMIE: Nothing. Come on, let’s go. Try and keep up, eh?
DOCTOR WHO: LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 29

ARTFUL DODGER: (CHUCKLES) Sorry!

DOCTOR: You wouldn’t know, Jamie. You wouldn’t remember.

JAMIE: Aye, thanks to Zoe here, and her ‘dayt-er ret-’

(RUNNING TO HALT) Where are we now?
Through the Gateway. In the Land of Fiction proper. I have to say, I like what they’ve done with it.
We’re in the Magic Forest.
Oh, aye-? It’s like something out of a fairy story.
Well, it would be. (FX: TINKLY FAIRY SOUND; FAIRY MATERIALISES) This is where the fairies live.

(FX: FAIRY FLUTTER-BUZZES PAST) Hey, get out of it —

We need to find this ‘Mistress’. She, I suspect, is the one who brought us here.

Where the Cybermen are.

(STEPPING FORWARD) Oh well, whatever you say —

. not so lovely?

The path it is, then —

Yes, Doctor-?
I’m curious to know how it was you arrived here.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 40
Oh! Well, it was a few weeks ago, I think. I was on the Wheel, and then I just sort of, woke up here.
Wearing a spacesuit-—?
Well, yes. I didn’t know where I was at first, but they gave me a data cluster.
Who did?
The fairies.
You mean one of those magic apples?
They’re not apples. But yes. It undid the locks the Time Lords put on my memory.
Which shouldn’t be possible.
In the real world, perhaps. But out here?
Hmm.
The Mistress’s agents had failed to locate you. I was sent to see if I could do any better.
You’ve met her then, this Mistress?
Oh no. It’s not personal, though: no-one has. (BEAT; CHANGING SUBJECT) So tell me, Doctor. What happened to you? I mean, to make you look so different?
Aye, that’s a good question-!
It’s a very long story.

Well, it’s a very long walk.

Yes, and it’s not going well. The Cybermen being here throws the natural order out of the window. The heroes of classic fiction were never written to provide effective opposition for half-human machine creatures. Their authors could never have imagined such things —
(APPROACHING FROM DOOR) Well, they could. That’s the point.

. Count Dracula. Welcome to Camelot. Come freely, go safely. And leave something of the happiness you bring!

BEAT

Doctor-?
Friend Doctor dislikes me, I think.
Hey, Doctor — give the man a chance.
That, Jamie, is a vampire. A blood-drinking revenant!
No he’s not. He’s a character from a book.
We are in the same room, you know?
Doctor, whatever’s got into you?
Suffice it to say there is history between his people and mine. Bad blood, you might say.
Oh. A clan thing. I know all about that. If I ever get my hands on a Campbell, he’1ll know all about it after what they did to us at Bannockburn!
The Count initially refused a commission. It was only when we lost Sherlock Holmes that we were able to persuade him to lead us.
An obvious choice. After all, he did lay waste to half of Europe.

SCENE 31: EXT. THE MAGIC FOREST (CONTINUOUS)
I wasn’t expecting this.

You weren’t expecting this? What about me? I had a life, back in Scotland. A full life, fighting the English, doing my best by my brothers and sisters in the clan McCrimmon. Then you come along, and you tell me about this whole other life I’ve forgotten. A strange, mad life, fighting monsters among the stars. And no sooner have I got my head around all that, than I find out this — that I’m, I don’t know, a figment of someone else’s imagination-?
It’s not all bad, you know.
Och, you just keep your nose out, lassie!
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 81
Jamie, Alice is our friend —

Can we leave my character flaws for some other time? This is a difficult moment for all of us, but right now, I think we should concentrate our minds on finding Zoe.
Aye, and this “Mistress”. Cos there are one or two things I'd like to say to her, as well!
Alice. No joy with establishing a radio link?
Not with Beauty here. The network’s overloaded, it looks like she’s crashed. There was a base station at Camelot, I wonder fe I
(CUTTING IN) So where to now?

Pass, on the fringes of his own domain. That’s where they’1l
be heading.

You’re thinking real world topography. The other side of the Pass is only a few miles further on. We should be able to meet them on the way down to the coast.
Good. Come on, Jamie. Whatever it is, we’ll get to the bottom of it. I promise. (WALKS)
(SIGHS) You and your promises. (WALKS) I’m comin’, I’m comin’...

SCENE 38: EXT. ENGLISH RIVERBANK/TRANSYLVANIAN MOUNTAINS
FX: FAIRYTALE MUSIC SOUNDS OF SUMMER

(EXAGGERATED NICENESS) I still dream of that day. The air was thick with the scent of meadow-sweet. I lay by the riverbank, breathing in the summer. I’d lost my sunhat, and sought the shade of a leafy willow. My eyes were so heavy, the grass as soft as silk.
FX: CUT TO — HOWLING WIND, OCCASIONAL WOLF, BATS SQUEAKING

Winter came early in Transylvania that year. One night the clouds cleared and I stood on the snow, bathed in moonlight, feeling the faint burn of the reflected sun on my skin, the memory of a warmth I had not felt for centuries. I cried the red tears of other men’s blood.
FX: CUT TO — FAIRYTALE MUSIC SOUNDS OF SUMMER
I sank down into the warm grass, and fell into a deep sleep.
FX: CUT TO — HOWLING WIND, OCCASIONAL WOLF, BATS SQUEAKING
I found the young woman lying by the frozen river. She had frost in her hair and on her lashes.
FX: CUT TO — FAIRYTALE MUSIC SOUNDS OF SUMMER
Soon it was nightfall. I heard the gentle sounds of woodland creatures. The snuffle of hedgehogs, the distant hoot of an owl.
FX: CUT TO — HOWLING WIND, OCCASIONAL WOLF, BATS SQUEAKING
She was wearing summer clothes, her throat exposed.
(FX: CUT TO — FAIRYTALE MUSIC SOUNDS OF SUMMER. A DISCORDANT NOTE. A FLUTTER OF BATS CREEPING IN)

FX: CUT TO — HOWLING WIND, OCCASIONAL WOLF, BATS SQUEAKING
I watched the jugular vein throbbing in her neck.

I lowered my eyes in shame, repulsed by what I had become.
FX: CUT TO — FAIRYTALE MUSIC SOUNDS OF SUMMER
Yes. Well, that’s vampirism for you. (EFFORT — CAN’T GET OUT) Just — come over here and help me out of this rabbit hole, would you? It’s a little snug.

NEMO: I work in my own interest, Doctor. But at this time, the interests of both myself and the Mistress coincide. She requested I dredge a certain something up from the seabed, to aid you in your fight...?
JAMIE: Not another of those giant squid things?
DOCTOR WHO: LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 114
NEMO: No. Something much more valuable. Behind you-?
ZOE: Doctor, look! He’s got your TARDIS!
DOCTOR: I don’t believe it-!
NEMO: The box has gathered a number of barnacles, but it seems otherwise undamaged —
DOCTOR: (FX: PATTING DOOR) Good to see you, old girl. Nemo? I need you to stay with the Nautilus. We’re expecting trouble. (FX:
UNLOCKING: DOOR) Jamie, Zoe — with me.
ALICE: Doctor? Where are you going?
DOCTOR: The Citadel. Obviously.
ALICE: Then I’m coming with you.
ROB ROY: Yes, and I.
DOCTOR: I’m sorry, no. I need you both here with Nemo.
ALICE: Whatever for? If the Cybermen attack, you’ll be over-run! You need soldiers.
ROB ROY: Aye! Someone to watch your back.
JAMIE: She’s got a point, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Against my better judgement —
JAMIE: Excellent!
ROB ROY: (WALKING INTO TARDIS, OFF) Budge up, Donald, man. There can barely be room to swing a cat in h—
DOCTOR WHO: LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 115
ALICE: (OFF) I say, it’s [bigger on the inside—]
ALICE: JAMIE and ZOE: (OFF) We know.
DOCTOR WHO: LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 116
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 47: INT. CASTLE FRANKENSTEIN
CYBERMEN: Units report loss of converted bio-mechanoid submarine.
CYBERMEN: CYBER-PLANNER: Enlarge report.
CYBERMAN: Aggressive weaponry from submersible craft. Data points to submarine designated “Nautilus”.
CYBERMAN: CYBER-PLANNER:
CYBERMAN: It is all that blocks our way to the Citadel. All available Cybermen and Cyber-converted bio-forms to cross the sea bed and attack.
CYBERMAN: Transmitting.
CYBERMAN: CYBER-PLANNER: We will destroy imagination. We will replace fiction and lies with fact and logic.
DOCTOR WHO: LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 117
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 48: INT. CITADEL (CORRIDOR/CONTROL CENTRE)
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: CORRIDOR OUTSIDE THE MASTER'S CONTROL CENTRE IN ‘THE MIND ROBBER’ — IE WITH CRAZY COMPUTER BRAIN SOUNDS, SLIGHTLY OFF)
DOCTOR: All clear. Rob Roy, Jamie, cover the entrances.
ROB ROY: (EXITING TARDIS) (FX: UNSHEATHING SWORD) Here, Donald — you'll be needing this!
JAMIE: (EXITING TARDIS) Aye, I’m in the mood to run a few Cybermen through. C’mon. (THEY HEAD OFF)
DOCTOR: Stay close to me, Zoe, Alice. If I remember right, the Control Centre proper was around about [here-]
KARKUS: (GERMAN ACCENT) You shall not pass.
ZOE: Doctor! Look! It’s the Karkus-!
ALICE: The who-?
DOCTOR: A comic strip character from the pages of the Hourly Telepress, if I recall.
ALICE: And I thought all the superheroes were dead.
ZOE: Hello, Karkus. Do you remember me? Your friend, Zoe?
KARKUS: I — remember. You — follow.
ZOE: Doctor, Alice — you heard the Karkus.
ZOE: (FX: DOCTOR, ALICE, ZOE FOLLOWING KARKUS THROUGH INTO CONTROL
CENTRE: PROPER. UP COMPUTER BRAIN EFFECTS)
DOCTOR WHO: LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 118
KARKUS: Mistress. Visitors.
MISTRESS: (SLIGHTLY OFF) Faithful Karkus. He never leaves my side. He could teleport himself away, but here he stays. Loyal unto death.
DOCTOR: The Mistress, I presume. If you turned on the lights, we’d be better able to see your face.
MISTRESS: Doctor. At last. I knew you’d come. I never once doubted you. Not for a second. I knew you’d find me.
ZOE: Why is her voice so familiar?
DOCTOR: (HARD) It’s alright, you can drop the pretence.
MISTRESS: Zoe... doesn’t know.
ZOE: Know what?
DOCTOR: You never told her?
ALICE: (IT’S BEGINNING TO DAWN ON HER) When she was asleep in the Magic Forest, it was like — she’d stopped. And then she was —
DOCTOR: . rebooted?
ZOE: You make me sound like a machine.
DOCTOR: (FX: WALKING ZOE FURTHER FORWARD) Look at her, Zoe. At the Mistress. Can’t you see? Haven’t you of all people worked it out yet?
MISTRESS: I’ve been here all this time. Trying to hold them off. Trying to remember stories from my childhood, finding ways to fight them. All this time, waiting for you to find me... Doctor.
DOCTOR WHO: LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 119
ZOE: It can’t be —
DOCTOR: It is. The Mistress of the Land of Fiction is the woman I once knew — as Zoe Herriot!
DOCTOR: END OF PART THREE

elements.text: PART FOUR
(FX: WALKING ZOE FURTHER FORWARD) Look at her, Zoe. At the Mistress. Can’t you see? Haven’t you of all people worked it out yet?
I’ve been here all this time. Trying to hold them off. Trying to remember stories from my childhood, finding ways to fight them. All this time, waiting for you to find me... Doctor.
ZOE? It can’t be —
It is. The Mistress of the Land of Fiction is the woman I once knew — as Zoe Herriot!
SCENE CONTINUES:
SCENE 49: INT. CITADEL (CONTROL CENTRE) (CONTINUED)
You’re — you’/re me.
Well? Would you care to explain what’s really going on, “Mistress”?
None of this is real. This is all a wonderful children’s adventure which adults adore.
It seems real enough to me.
MISTRESS. Oh, but it would, Doctor. Look at your journey here. Pseudo- historical to base-under-siege. Right at home.
You’re viewing this from some other level of consciousness, aren’t you?
It alters you, this place. You experience things differently.
What happened to you? Zoe?
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 121
FX: JAMIE COMES RUNNING THROUGH FROM CORRIDOR
Hey, Doctor — there’s Cybermen all over the beach at the foot of the cl-[iffs!] — (SEES MISTRESS) Och, hello there, hen.
James Robert McCrimmon. The bravest boy in all of Scotland. Oh, how I’ve missed you, Jamie.
GROWLS
Don’t be jealous, Karkus. Jamie’s our friend.
(ASIDE) Doctor, is that really the Mistress?
(ASIDE) Apparently so.
(ASIDE) So how come she looks like Zoe’s older sister?
What were you saying, Jamie? About the Cybermen?
Oh, right. They’re walking up from under the sea.
That explains the disturbance Nemo picked up in the Nautilus!
Aye, well — Rob and I, we can’t hold them off forever, not with dirk and claymore!
Karkus will give you weapons. Show him, Karkus.
Ja! (HE & JAMIE EXIT)
(FX: FOLLOWING) Wait! I’m coming with you-!
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 122
SCENE 50: INT. CASTLE FRANKENSTEIN
FX: AS BEFORE
CYBER-PLANNER:
Assume attack formation. All human elements are to be retained for Cyber-conversion, except one. The Mistress must not be destroyed.
Confirmed.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 123
SCENE 51: INT. CITADEL APPROACH
(FX: JAMIE & ALICE RUSHING DOWN STEPS, CLATTERING BADOLIERS,
ETC)
Donald, lad — they’re nearly on us!
It’s alright, Rob. (FX: PASSING GUN) See? Weapons!
What in the name o’ Hamish do you do with these-?
(FX: KA-CHUNK) We’ll be firing armour-plated rounds loaded with a radioactive acetone suspension.
Aye, but how do they work?
Point them at a Cyberman and press the button.
Great. What’s a Cyberman?
(FX: OFF, APPROACHING ON SHINGLE) Surrender. All characters
will surrender.
One of them. Silver Englishman.
Those things-? They’re English-?
I reckon. Don’t you-?
FX: GUN BEING COCKED
Hey-hey! This day just gets better!
Ready, boys? Aim.. and FIRE!!!
FX: FURIOUS VOLLEY OF HI-TECH GATLING SOUNDS
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 124
SCENE 52: EXT. BEACH BELOW CITADEL
(FX: WAVES. CYBERMEN ADVANCING ON SHINGLE... INTO DEFENSIVE FIRE)
HOWLS, COLLAPSES
Alert Castle Frankenstein. We have encountered resistance. Require immediate reinforcements.
FX: MORE FIRE, MORE FALLING CYBERMEN
All units retreat into the water and await further orders.
FX: CYBERMEN TRUDGE BACK. CROSS TO:
SCENE 53: INT. CITADEL APPROACH
Did you see that? We’ve got them on the run!
No. They’re buying themselves time until reinforcements get here.
Aye, and I’m betting that won’t be long.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 125
SCENE 54: (LINKED SEQUENCE) 54A: INT. CITADEL (CONTROL CENTRE)
FX: ATMOS AS BEFORE
I don’t understand. Why are there two of me?
I’m not entirely sure there are.
You mean she’s not real? Oh. Or I’m not.
Zoe, this is the Land of Fiction. Words like “real” don’t really belong here.
Neither do we.
I forget, what a clever little thing I was. No, you do not belong here.
If you really are my friend Zoe Herriot, then I want to be here more than ever. Now, we don’t have much time. Tell us everything.
Everything-?
From the beginning, please.
FX: CROSSFADE INTO:
54B: INT. WHEEL IN SPACE (FLASHBACK)
(FX: B/G SOUNDS OF PEOPLE WORKING, MACHINES BLEEPING, AIR HISSING. )

It was years later, aboard Station Three — the Wheel in Space. I was remembering how we’d fought the Cybermen together, you, Jamie and I; how we’d driven them off the Wheel; how you and Jamie had got in your TARDIS and left. But as I watched your ship fade from view, the strangest feeling came over me. So I went for a medical, went to see Gemma Corwyn’s replacement. Do you know what he found?
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 126
Enlighten me.

I was two years older, medically speaking, than I’d been a few hours before. Well, I worked it out for myself. You’re a time traveller. I must have gone with you and been returned, my memories wiped. I wondered why you’d done that.
Zoe, I had nothing to do with that.
I worked that out later.
FX: CROSSFADE INTO:
54C: EXT. SPACE (FLASHBACK)
FX: SOUND OF BREATHING IN SPACE SUIT
Months passed. I was outside, observing the remnants of Messier-13, when I saw the ship. A Cyberman raiding party. There was no time to warn anyone.
FX: SOUNDS OF CYBERGUNS; EXPLOSIONS RAKING HULL OF WHEEL
FX: CROSSFADE INTO:
54D: INT. CITADEL (CONTROL CENTRE)

There were three of them, and a Cyber-Planner. They began converting the crew at once. People I’d known for years. Leo Ryan, do you remember him? They got me when I was forced to come back in for air. They took me aboard their ship.
Didn’t you try and fight them?
But I am fighting them!
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 127
SCENE 55: EXT. BEACH BELOW CITADEL
FX: CYBERMEN MARCHING ON SHINGLE, OFF
Alright, looks like they’re coming up for a second go.
(FX: KA-CHUNK) Aye, well — we’ve got plenty to give ‘em!
I’m not so sure. (FX: BUZZ OF RADIO STATIC) What was that-?
Och, aye. It’ll be this ‘ray-dio’ that Nemo gave me.
Radio-? Why didn’t you say-?
Didn’t see as it mattered, hen.
Give me that-! (INTO RADIO) Lieutenant Alice Liddell, receiving —
(RADIO DISTORT) Lieutenant, the Nautilus has withdrawn to safer waters.
(SARCASTIC) Wonderful. So we’re on our own-?
(D) Not exactly. There are reinforcements coming. They should be with you any moment now.
FX: MASSED-FLUTTER-BUZZING IN THE SKY: A SWARM OF FAIRIES
Look! Up in the sky. There’s thousands of them! They’re tiny, mind.
Och, no —
What are they? Bees, or what?
(INTO RADIO) Thank you, Captain! (FX: RADIO OFF) We might have even have a chance now.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 128
Seriously, what are those things?
Promise you won’t laugh? Fairies.
Oh. Are your Cybermen in for a kicking, or what?
(FX: THE FAIRIES DESCEND ON THE APPROACHING CYBERMEN. SMALL,
VOICES RAISED IN A HALF SCREECH HALF SONG)
SCREECHING AS THEY’RE ATTACKED
OVER THIS:
Och, that’s brutal. You’d never know that creatures so small and so beautiful would have it in them!
Aye. You don’t want to mess with fairies! Vicious wee things.
They’re retreating again. Now, we need to keep the pressure up. (FX: RADIO REACTIVATED) Nautilus, come in please!
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 129
SCENE 56: INT. BRIDGE — THE NAUTILUS
FX: ATMOS AS PER ‘WRECK OF THE TITAN’
Nautilus receiving.
(RADIO) We’re pushing the Cybermen back into the sea. They’1l be sheltering in depressions on the ocean floor.
And you want me to dispose of them-?
(RADIO) If you could.
Then, they will not escape the spur of the Nautilus. (ASIDE) Torpedo room! Stand by for launch.
(RUSHING UP) Nemo! Nemo, beware-!
Dracula. I am engaged in the business of retribution. What is you want -?
In the porthole. There are... creatures outside!
Cybermen?
Only from the waist up.
(RUSHING TO PORTHOLE) God in Heaven. (INTO RADIO) Lieutenant Liddell? The Cybermen have converted mermaids.
(D) Oh, that’s just wrong-!
FX: MERMAIDS BATTERING THE HULL FROM OUTSIDE, SCRATCHING
They are trying to claw their way in-!
On the Nautilus, men’s hearts never fail them. The double shell is as firm as iron —
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 130
FX: OMINOUS RENDINGS
Yes, but paper to these cybernetic harpies!
FX: ALARM KLAXON
My Nautilus! My beautiful ship! (ASIDE) Fire torpedoes!
FX: SWOOSHING THROUGH WATER. SCRATCHING CONTINUES
Captain — you must surface! The mermaids will soon breach the hull!
Count, your cheerlessness serves no purpose. Pass me that canister.
This-?

Yes, sir, that canister, sir! In here, Count Dracula, is a manuscript written in several languages. It contains the sum of my studies of the sea, and the story of my life; and God willing, it will not perish with me. The last survivor of all of us on board the Nautilus will throw this case into the sea, and it will go wherever it is borne by the waves.
Captain, I may be dead, but you are not-!
(ASIDE) Torpedo room — ready another volley!
FX: EXPLOSION FROM OFF, IN THE TORPEDO ROOM
What was that-?
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 131
SCENE 57: EXT. BEACH BELOW CITADEL
FX: FAIRIES FIGHTING, CYBERMEN DYING, CYBERGUNS
(D) (FX: FLOODING WATER IN B/G) Lieutenant, this is Nautilus. Mermaids have forced their way through our torpedo tubes. Now there are Cybermen aboard, [and —]
(D, OFF) Nemo, behind you-!
(D, OFF) You will submit. You will surrender.
(D) (SEEING CYBERMEN) Almighty God, enough! [Enough! —]
FX: STATIC
Nautilus! Nautilus! Come in, please!
It’s no good, lassie.
You don’t understand. We’ve lost the Nautilus!
Aye. Now keep under cover, let the fairies do their work.
(FX: SOUNDS OF CYBER TROLLS COMING UP OUT OF THE WATER,
UP BEACH, ECHOING FOOTSTEPS, LIKE DINOSAURS )
What are those — things?!?
Well, now we know what happened to all the trolls.
They’re cyber-trolls, aye!
The fairies won’t be able to puncture their skin as easily as they did the normal Cybermen.
So what do we do?
Fire. And keep firing, until they’re dead. Or we are.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 132
Then — let’s gi’em laldy!
FX: THEY BEGIN FIRING AT TROLLS
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 133
SCENE 58: (LINKED SEQUENCE) 58A: INT. CYBERSHIP (FLASHBACK)
FX: FADE UP: CYBER-SHIP INTERIOR. BLEEPS AND MACHINE HISSES
Go on.

Well, slight as I was, I wasn’t going to make much of a Cyberman, they could see that much. But they tested my intelligence, and decided that my brain would make me a fine Cyber-Planner. (BEAT) Which is rather flattering, actually.
Zoe, the human computer. Nothing changes.

As their probes dug into my consciousness, something budged. The mental blocks placed by the Time Lords fell off, and it all came flooding back. The TARDIS, our travels together, all those wonderful adventures. I remembered how the Time Lords had captured you, and had sent Jamie and I back to our own time.
FX: CROSSFADE INTO:
58B: INT. CITADEL (CONTROL CENTRE)
Should I really be hearing this? I mean, won’t the Time Lords be awfully cross?
I think it’ll be alright, Zoe.
FX: CROSSFADE BACK TO:
58C: INT. CYBERSHIP (FLASHBACK)
FX: BLEEPS AND MACHINE HISSES

I realised — if my mind was open to their systems, their systems were open to my mind. I calculated how to send a feedback wave to the Cybership — and took control of their propulsion systems, punching a hole in space-time, transporting them somewhere I knew they could do no more harm.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 134
So you brought them here.
FX: SOUND OF SCREAMING ENGINES, EXPLOSION
The Cybership split in half as it crashed into the Void. The only advantage I had was that I knew where we were, and knew I had to reach the Control Centre. So I ran —
FX: SILENCE. CONTINUES INTO:
58D: INT. CITADEL (CONTROL CENTRE)

. I ran here. Well, to what remained of here. The computer had been terribly damaged, but — well, I plugged myself in, and my consciousness did most of the work. The Land of Fiction unfolded around me.
And you’ve been fighting the Cybermen ever since?
MISTRESS.

Yes. Initially, I brought characters from stories to life, but the Cybermen could easily outwit them. All stories have a logic of their own, and Cybermen are good with logic. So I gave the characters free will. I made them cunning and unpredictable. Of course, that means some of them went mad in the process. Some of them became just cruel, or greedy.
Yes. We’ve met some of those. The space leeches-—?
Oh, them. Some of Karkus’s enemies, from the pages of the Hourly Telepress.
Yes, and that devil Merodach, too —
Merodach-? One moment —
FX: COMPUTER BURBLES. TELEPRINTER
(READING) ‘Merodach’. Source: The Brownie of the Black Haggs. Author: Hogg, James. 1770-1835.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 135
Please, Doctor, don’t get the wrong impression. There was always more good than bad.
Dodger and Oliver. Nemo and Rob Roy. Alice and Dracula.
But nonetheless — the Land of Fiction was by now a more dangerous place than ever?
Yes — even without the Cybermen on the march, converting all the beings they could find. I needed help. I needed someone who could put things right, and defeat the Cybermen. I needed you, Doctor.
And so — you re-created me?
Don’t think I didn’t try. I novelized all of our adventures.
(SLIGHTLY OFF) Here they are, on the bookshelves, see?
(READING OFF TITLES) Doctor Who and the Dominators. Doctor Who and the Krotons. Doctor Who and the Laird of McCrimmon — I don’t remember that!
Well, I had to make some up of my own. Don’t worry, Doctor. It turns out you’re just too unlikely a character ever to be successfully recreated, even here.
One of a kind! Unique!
‘Absurd’, the computer labelled you.
So — the Doctor here’s the real thing?
Of course. I opened a small hole in space-time and sent a stream of data through, locked onto the TARDIS’ navigational circuits. I’m very, very clever, as you know.
So that’s how I landed up here!
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 136

As ever, the TARDIS managed to scramble the data a little, you arrived way off target. So I created a friend for you, someone to keep you safe — and built an environment around him, somewhere he’d thrive.
Jamie!
Yes, and literary Scotland.

I’d remembered him so well, every detail of him. I was a young girl, then, and he was so very pretty. I remembered him so well that when I re-created him, he took on a life of his own, almost at once. But in the absence of his memories of you, he created his own back story. A heroic past. It put years on him.
But you took away his memories of me because-?
To give you a mystery to solve. So you’d stick with him. So you’d stay. And to prevent him from inadvertently fictionalising you.
Poor Jamie.
He deserved better, I know. The next thing I knew, there you were in the Atlantic —
. re-arranging the deckchairs on the Titanic. Literally.
You shouldn’t say that around here. It’s not a safe word.
So then you sent Nemo to find us-?
I'd set my best agents to search for you. And when, finally, I’d got you in the Void...
You re-created me.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 137
I made you seconds before you bumped into Jamie. I thought I'd better give you and Jamie your memories back, to avoid any further complications.
Yes, I think you’d complicated your plot quite enough.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 138
SCENE 59: INT. CASTLE FRANKENSTEIN
FX: AS BEFORE
CYBER-PLANNER:
Cyber-converted fictional life forms are suffering unacceptable losses. Cyber-converted magical creatures are still susceptible to magical attack. We must again warp the consensus reality.
That will require a large expenditure of energy.
CYBER-PLANNER:
Release control of the attacking force. The conservation of energy will be enough to power the device. In the confusion we will advance and conquer.
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 139
SCENE 60: INT. CITADEL (CONTROL CENTRE)
So.. I’m a fictional being?
I’m sorry, Zoe. You’ve every right to be angry.
Angry? I think it’s a brilliant plan. Drag the Cybermen away from real time, trap them here in a war with people who don’t even exist, and wait for the Doctor. It’s genius. I’ma genius!
Except that the Cybermen saw other possibilities, didn’t they?
FX: COMPUTER BEGINS TO MAKE ANGRY NOISES
What does that mean-?
& MISTRESS: Trouble!
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 140
SCENE 61: EXT. BEACH BELOW CITADEL
FX: HEROES FIRING. TROLLS STOMPING FORWARD - TO SUDDEN HALT
Hey! They’ve just stopped. What’s got into them?
Hold your fire, people.
FX: CEASE FIRING
They’re frozen like statues. Are they dead?
FX: FADE IN PSYCHEDELIC REALITY EFFECT FROM SCENE 37
Hear that? They’re going to alter our perception again.
Och, no —
What’s happening? What are they going to do to us?
Hold on to each other. Hold tightly, we need to stay together! Whatever happens, don’t let go of your rifle. Remember, none of this is real! Say it!
That’s nonsense. Of course this is real —
(GRIMLY) Right now, this is as real as anything else I’ve seen in my life! (BEAT. HAPPILY) Oh look! Scotland! —
FX: TO CRESCENDO. CUT
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 141
SCENE 62: (LINKED SEQUENCE)
62A: EXT. SCOTTISH HIGHLANDS
FX: FADE UP. WIND WHISTLING THROUGH HEATHER
What was all that about?
I don’t know. Did we just get very, very drunk?
No. But it’s a decent enough idea.
Perhaps we went mad.
ROY. Perhaps I went mad and I imagined you.
Perhaps. Because If I were imagining you I’d have imagined someone a wee bit prettier.
Hey. I’m pretty! (SEEING ALICE) So’s she. Well hello there, lassie-!
Cybermen. Behind you.
FX: THE FX, MUSIC, ALL STOPS TO A HALT
62B: NARRATION

Jamie pushed Alice out of harm’s way, grabbing a large two- handed sword, conveniently left for him in the grass. Rob Roy drew his own sword, and side by side the two friends hurled themselves at the enemy. The Cybermen aimed their reality altering weapon at the two charging Highlanders, saying:
62C: EXT. THE SCOTTISH HIGHLANDS
Shift in altered fictional reality not at sufficient strength.
Increased levels required. Engage.
MUSIC: BAGPIPES
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL)
FX: TO MATCH ACTION OUTLINED IN FOLLOWING
Then Rob Roy turned to meet the foe The claymore flashing to and fro And struck the giant head to toe Until the monster fell dejected.
The joy of battle flushed his face He struck three more dead apace Proud warrior of the Highland Race With passion unexpected.
“You'll never beat McCrimmon yet!” Jamie bellowed at the silver threat And once more with battle met
And vigour undefeated,
His muscles stretched, his sinews keen, He slew the half-man half-machine
(With Gaelic threats the most obscene And better un-translated. )
“Craig an tuire!” -
— the warriors cried
Their chests swelled up with Celtic pride The Cybermen stopped in their stride
And hastily retreated.
“Come back!, my hairy Highland friends,” Alice cried, at her wits’ end.
“Turn and flee the Cybermen!”
She heartily entreated.
“This skirmish lark is but a snare, Designed to take you unaware.
The real battle’s going on up there!” She said, as she departed.
FX: BEGIN TO FADE OUT B/G FX
“Come on” said Jamie, as he ran McCrimmon and MacGregor clans
United, though the words now scanned...
CUT TO:
Page
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 143
SCENE 63: EXT. BEACH BELOW CITADEL (CONTINUOUS)
. Differently/As if reality had shifted back once more and they found themselves in a more naturalistic setting.
Who are you talking to?
Said Rob Roy. What?
Come on! The Cybermen are still not moving. Alice says we need
to get indoors before their ship lands.
Ship? I see no ship —
FX: CYBERSHIP ABOVE, COMING IN TO LAND
Their ‘space-ship’?
Och, that sort of ship. (RUNS)
LEGEND OF THE CYBERMEN by Mike Maddox (FINAL) Page 144
SCENE 64: INT. CITADEL (CONTROL CENTRE)
FX: FADE UP — ALICE’S RUNNING FOOTSTEPS
Doctor-!
Alice. Any news from Nemo?
They were boarded. I think they’re dead.
But Dracula was a vampire. How could he die?
FX: JAMIE AND ROB ROY RUNNING UP
(BREATHLESS) Doctor! Seal all the doors!
(BREATHLESS) Aye, there’s a Cybership outside. They’re landing!
Er, Jamie —
